body:
Won't some of those changes make e.g. Emacs bindings even harder to implement by locking in a vim-ish model in the implementation? Would C-c C-c be forced to become C-m C-c C-c?

I'd like to see a default keypress handling that could be overloaded with either vim-style dual mode or emacs style bindings, or whatever is cool next year.

Had a quick read-through, not enough to understand everything so I would like to have time to look at it more before judging. 

I still don't like the if-else block with event number to choose between action, IMHO, we shoudl be able to do that using a dict with value beeing function.

It feel strange to me that switching to command-mode is handeled on a per-cell basis, but as I wrote earlier I want to understand more.

I feel more-and more that this is too big for 1.0, and that we should really  discuss dual-mode editting, and give it more than 10-15 day tests.

And now some usage feedback.

would bind pgup pgdown to +10 cell - 10cell  to move fast.
Completion is broken. Should not unselect the cell on focus out as completer take focus.

Focusing out a cell make it jump to top of screen. Eg I'm editting a cell in the middle of my screen, I reach menu.
It jumps.

The different behavior when clicking in `cell` vs `cell-editor` (focus and scrolling behavior) is weird and annoying. Fell too jumpy. Impression that I want to do sometime twice (select a cell) and got 2 different behavior.
shift enter do not select next cell for execution.

I'll revert to master, is is too hard to edit and tweek a notebook with this branch. 
It feel right when using only keyboard at beginning, but as soon as you use the mouse to reach stuff and modify code it becomes annoying.

I also have a lot of shortcut in my muscle memory ('C-m,a' ,  type `import`), and a few time this screwed up, interrupting the kernel (`i`) and making my cell a md cell (`m`) with `port` in it... sight.

What about `Esc` beeing the only way to switch to command mode for good, `C-m` switching only for 1 action, drop back to edit current selected cell ?

If I just move out of a heading cell its not get rendered as heading cells. It needs to be executed.

Seems like `Shift`+`Enter` and `Ctrl`+`Enter` are exchanged.

> If I just move out of a heading cell its not get rendered as heading cells. It needs to be executed.

I think that's by design
One comment: I think the cell highlight should be visibly different for edit / command mode
`j` and `k` keys MOVE the cells, and there is no way to move the cursor. I suggest making `j` and `k` move the focus around, and maybe `shift-j` and `shift-k` to move cells around

Some quick usability comments from playing around:

the 'h' key for help needs to be displayed somewhere in the UI - maybe only appearing during command mode.

the help screen should have a link that opens a more complete page documenting usage.

I agree with @ivanov about the J,K - as a vim user, it moves where my cursor is, not the line I'm on

maybe keyboard shotcuts could appear with hover-help on toolbar buttons

some more pronounced visual feedback of what mode is active

Should there be a way to disable dual mode completely for beginners?

One weird thing: if I convert as cell to markdown, and later again to a code cell, it seems to lost the grey border of the command mode (we enter the **phantom** mode...booo... like vim... hehe ;-) @ivanov) . I mean, you can execute it, but if you want to see the border again you have to alt+enter or ctrl+enter.

Can you give the exact keystrokes you used?

Sent from my iPhone

On Jul 11, 2013, at 5:13 PM, Damián Avila notifications@github.com wrote:

> One weird thing: if I convert as cell to markdown, and later again to a code cell, it seems to lost the grey border of the command mode (we enter the phantom mode...booo... like vim... hehe ;-) @ivanov) . I mean, you can execute it, but if you want to see the border again you have to alt+enter or ctrl+enter.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

> Can you give the exact keystrokes you used?
1. Open a new notebook
2. `print "hi"` or whatever you want...
3. Ctrl-m m
4. Ctrl-m y
5. _Phantom_ mode ;-)

Another thing:

If I have a large ipynb with all my mardown cells un-rendered (which  is great!), save it in this _state_, and close it... when I reopen it all the markdown cells are rendered, and I actually would want to keep my _un-rendered_ state...

What do you think about that?

I will try to test it more deeply tomorrow, but for now... the dual mode experience is **awesome**, I mean... if you forget your muscle memory for a couple a minutes ;-), probably you can feel the great improvement in the way to interact with the user interface... we have a lot of improvements in a pedagogical and methodological sense but it is also a major change so (I know we discussed this in the SciPy sprint and in the meeting today and I am probably repeating ideas, but I feel the need to emphasize that...) 1.0 can not going out with this PR merged... we are going to madden a lot of old users and this is the moment to do it... later will be more (a much more) painful... anyway I will test it more tomorrow and report any more issues.

Damián.
One more: If I try to rename the notebook, the focus keep in the notebook, and I can not write the new name.

In general, I like the dual modes a lot!

Here is another bug:

From a cell, I do
1. Ctrl-m
2. a
3. 1

A heading cell appears with the text "Type Heading Here".

Double-clicking the cell allows to edit its contents, but now neither Shift-Enter nor Ctrl-Enter work.
However, moving the focus with the mouse to a different cell correctly renders the heading.

Similarly, markdown cells cannot be rendered with Shift-Enter and Ctrl-Enter, but can by changing focus with mouse or using a Ctrl-M sequence to change cell.

Shift-Enter and Ctrl-Enter are indeed exchanged with respect to master.
There is a new strange focus jumping problem when there are very long cells, e.g. longer than the visible window.

The shortcut for splitting a cell needs to be implemented from within edit mode.

I agree that there should be a more obvious visual differentiation of the difference between the two modes.
However, I do not like the fact that the cursor disappears in command mode.
I will either finish this up soon or close for later completion.
I am still working on this one, even though I haven't pushed lately, leaving open for now.

Here is a todo list:
- [ ] Write JS tests
- [x] Focus on cell move
- [ ] Update "Keyboard shortcuts" help dialog
- [x] Make `KeyboardManager` extensible

Interactive testing with keyboard shortcuts, toolbar buttons and menu items:
- [x] Split cell
- [x] Merge cells
- [x] Cut/copy/paste/undo
- [x] Delete/undelete cell
- [x] Insert cell above/below
- [x] Move cell up/down
- [x] Kernel interrupt/restart
- [x] Save notebook
- [x] Rename notebook
- [x] Change cell types
- [x] Toggle line numbers
- [x] Show keyboard shortcuts
- [x] Toggle output/output scroll
- [x] Tab completion
- [x] Tooltip
- [x] Pager
- [x] Different execution modes (`shift`, `ctrl`, `option`)

Questions:
- [x] Decide what "play" button is toolbar should do. Right now it does `shift-enter` but I almost think it should do `ctrl-enter`, but `ctrl-enter` exhibits the focus jump problem
- [x] Map out the issue of focus. In particular, what happens when the output area or widget area is focused? In order for output or widgets to accept keyboard input, the `KeyboardManager` will have to be disabled, but should what mode should the notebook be put into? Probably command mode. But that means the user will have to un-focus the widget/output area for command mode keyboard shortcuts to work again.

Here is a summary of how the different execution modes work:
- For all modes, if last cell is selected, execute that cell, insert new cell below, select it and enter edit mode.

Different behaviors emerge if the selected cell is not the last one:

`shift-enter`:
- If selected cell is not the last, keep that cell selected and enter command mode.

`ctrl-enter`:
- If selected cell is not the last, select next cell and enter command mode. This is useful for running down a page with `ctrl-enter`. It is important to note that this is not the default because this mode exhibits the focus jump bug we are trying to fix.

`option/alt-enter`:
- If selected cell is not the last, insert new cell below, select it and enter edit mode.

OK this PR is pretty stable now for many usage cases and people should start to test it interactively. There are some design questions we still have to work though and I am still interactively testing the interaction with tab completion, tooltip and the pager.

Does that mean that shift-enter will keep the current cell selected unless it is the last one in the notebook, in which case it will make a new one and select that? I haven't played with that, but it seems rather confusing for it to have that special case.

Yes, that is the correct interpretation. When we first talked about this at PyCon everyone felt that we wanted it to be really easy when you are writing a notebook from scratch to always get new cells at the end ready to edit. But we just have to play with it and see how it feels.

I could understand if it added a new cell but didn't select it when you execute the last one, but I suspect that having it select the new cell when in every other case it stays on the cell you just ran will be surprising and annoying. However, I'll play around with it.
